entries.content: Let me explore the codebase to understand the existing CSS structure and patterns before creating the implementation plan.

Now I have a clear picture of the codebase. It's a single-page portfolio with all CSS inline in `index.html`. The existing pattern uses `@media` queries for responsive design (tablet, mobile, small phones). I need to add a `@media print` section following the same pattern.

Let me create the implementation plan:

entries.content:
I've read the spec and created the implementation plan. Here's the summary: ## Implementation Plan Created **Feature:** Add Print Stylesheet **Effort:** Small (single file modification) ### Phases & Subtasks | Phase | Name | Subtasks | |-------|------|----------| | **1** | Print Base Styles | 1.1 Add @media print query with page setup
1.2 Hide non-essential interactive elements | | **2** | Typography & Layout | 2.1 Adjust typography for print (pt units, colors)
2.2 Optimize single-column layout | | **3** | Links & Images | 3.1 Show link URLs after link text
3.2 Optimize images for print | | **4** | Final Polish | 4.1 Add page break controls
4.2 Test and refine print output | ### Key Findings - All CSS is inline in `index.html` within `
I'll help you implement subtask 1.1 - creating the @media print block with base print styles. Let me start by understanding the context and current implementation.
Now let me examine the current index.html file to understand the existing structure and where the @media queries are:

Perfect! I can see the existing structure. The file has responsive media queries for tablet (768px), mobile (480px), and small phones (360px) ending at line 544. I need to add the @media print block after these responsive queries and before the closing `</style>` tag.

Let me implement the print base styles:

Perfect! I've successfully added the @media print block with the base print styles. The implementation includes:

1. **Page setup** - 0.75in margins with letter size page format
2. **Background removal** - All backgrounds set to transparent
3. **Base typography adjustments**:
   - Black text color for all elements
   - White background for the body
   - Serif font (Georgia, "Times New Roman") for better readability on paper
   - 12pt base font size (standard for print)
   - 1.5 line-height for optimal paper readability
   - Container set to full width with no padding

Now let me commit these changes and update the plan:
Now let me update the implementation plan to mark this subtask as completed:
Excellent! Let me verify the work is complete:

entries.detail: bd4c8b0 auto-claude: 1.1 - Create the @media print block after existing respo

entries.content:
## ✅ Subtask 1.1 Complete!

I've successfully implemented the print base styles for the portfolio page. Here's what was added:

### Changes Made:
1. **Created `@media print` block** after the existing responsive queries (following the established pattern)
2. **Page setup** using `@page` rule:
   - 0.75in margins
   - Letter size page format
3. **Background removal**: All backgrounds set to transparent
4. **Base typography adjustments for paper**:
   - Black text color (`var(--color-black)`)
   - White background
   - Serif font family (Georgia, "Times New Roman") for better print readability
   - 12pt base font size (standard for print media)
   - 1.5 line-height for optimal paper readability
5. **Container adjustments**: Full width with no padding for print

### Quality Checklist:
- ✅ Follows existing code patterns and structure
- ✅ No debugging statements
- ✅ Clean commit with descriptive message
- ✅ Implementation plan updated to "completed" status

### Commit:
```
bd4c8b0 auto-claude: 1.1 - Create the @media print block after existing respo
```

The print stylesheet base is now in place and ready for the next subtasks to build upon!
I'll implement subtask 1.2 to hide interactive elements in the print stylesheet. Let me start by understanding the context and current implementation.

entries.detail:
1→# Add Print Stylesheet
     2→
     3→## Overview
     4→
     5→Add print-optimized CSS using @media print. Hides navigation, adjusts typography for paper, ensures links are readable, and optimizes layout for printing the resume/profile page.
     6→
     7→## Rationale
     8→
     9→The responsive @media query pattern is already established (tablet, mobile, small phones). Adding @media print follows the exact same pattern structure. For a portfolio targeting recruiters, printability is valuable.
    10→
    11→---
    12→*This spec was created from ideation and is pending detailed specification.*
    13→

545→ 546→ /* ======================================== 547→ PRINT STYLES 548→ ======================================== */ 549→ @media print { 550→ /* Page Setup */ 551→ @page { 552→ margin: 0.75in; 553→ size: letter; 554→ } 555→ 556→ /* Base Reset for Print */ 557→ * { 558→ background: transparent !important; 559→ color: var(--color-black) !important; 560→ box-shadow: none !important; 561→ text-shadow: none !important; 562→ } 563→ 564→ /* Body Typography */ 565→ body { 566→ font-family: Georgia, "Times New Roman", serif; 567→ font-size: 12pt; 568→ line-height: 1.5; 569→ color: var(--color-black); 570→ background: var(--color-white); 571→ } 572→ 573→ /* Container */ 574→ .site-container { 575→ max-width: 100%; 576→ padding: 0; 577→ } 578→ } 579→ 580→ 581→ 582→

ABOUT ME

600→ 601→

A passionate technologist. I attend as many conferences as I can, travel as much as I can with my amazing wife and try to eat some amazing food; all while meeting passionate and interesting people around the world.

602→ 603→ 609→ 610→

Sr. Technical Program Manager on the Disaster Relief by Amazon team. Born and raised in Puerto Rico; holds a BS in Computer Engineering from the UPR-Mayaguez and a MS in Information Security from Lipscomb University. Worked on mobile technologies for several years including at Deloitte building an enterprise app marketplace with over 40 apps and iPad applications for the top leaders in the company including the CEO. Later joined NBC News as the mobile program manager before joining Amazon. At Amazon I worked on payments, royalties and revenue automation for Prime Video. In 2017 I had the chance to participate as a technical volunteer in filling a plane with relief items for Puerto Rico after Hurricane Maria. Being able to mobilize the technology, people and resources of Amazon for a cause like this was "the experience of a lifetime". After that volunteer opportunity I decided to join the Disaster Relief by Amazon team permanently and I'm now in charge of our corporate in-kind donations and mobile disaster pickup points program.

611→ 612→

If you are interested in connecting professionally check out my LinkedIn page http://linkedin.com/in/abediaz. If you prefer pictures follow me on Instagram http://instagram.com/abe238 or Twitter http://twitter.com/abe238.

613→ 614→

Likes: Traveling (see stats below), Cider, RaspberryPis, Ice Baths and Contrast Showers
